verification_notes:
Independent check for n=2 closes exactly.
1) For p(x)=x^2+a_1x+a_2 with roots r,s:
Phi_2(p)=\left(\frac1{r-s}\right)^2+\left(\frac1{s-r}\right)^2=\frac{2}{(r-s)^2}.
So 1/Phi_2(p)=(r-s)^2/2=disc(p)/2=(a_1^2-4a_2)/2.
2) MSS coefficient rule at n=2:
c_k=\sum_{i+j=k}\frac{(2-i)!(2-j)!}{2!(2-k)!}a_i b_j, with a_0=b_0=1.
Hence c_1=a_1+b_1.
For k=2, weights are 1 (i,j)=(2,0),(0,2), and w(2,1,1)=\frac{1!1!}{2!0!}=1/2, so
c_2=a_2+b_2+\frac12 a_1b_1.
3) Key cancellation:
\Delta(p\boxplus_2 q)=c_1^2-4c_2
=(a_1+b_1)^2-4\left(a_2+b_2+\frac12a_1b_1\right)
=a_1^2+2a_1b_1+b_1^2-4a_2-4b_2-2a_1b_1
=(a_1^2-4a_2)+(b_1^2-4b_2)
=\Delta(p)+\Delta(q).
Therefore
1/Phi_2(p\boxplus_2 q)=\Delta(p\boxplus_2 q)/2=\Delta(p)/2+\Delta(q)/2=1/Phi_2(p)+1/Phi_2(q),
so surplus = 0 (equality).

verification_notes:
The centering reduction is correct, with one notation caveat about shift sign.

1) Phi_n translation invariance: for roots \(\lambda_i\),
\[\Phi_n(p)=\sum_i\left(\sum_{j\ne i}\frac1{\lambda_i-\lambda_j}\right)^2.\]
After shifting all roots by \(c\), each denominator becomes \((\lambda_i+c)-(\lambda_j+c)=\lambda_i-\lambda_j\), so \(\Phi_n\) is unchanged.

2) Translation covariance of \(\boxplus_n\):
Using \(p_A(x)=\det(xI-A)\), define \(\tau_t p(x)=p(x-t)=p_{A+tI}(x)\). Then
\[\tau_\alpha p_A\boxplus_n\tau_\beta p_B
=\mathbb E_Q\det\big(xI-(A+\alpha I)-Q(B+\beta I)Q^*\big)
=\mathbb E_Q\det\big((x-\alpha-\beta)I-(A+QBQ^*)\big)
=\tau_{\alpha+\beta}(p_A\boxplus_n p_B).\]
So roots shift by \(\alpha+\beta\), and \(\Phi_n\) is preserved.

Independent symbolic expansion checks:
- n=2: fully expanded difference
\( (p(x+\alpha)\boxplus_2 q(x+\beta))-(p\boxplus_2 q)(x+\alpha+\beta)=0\).
- n=3: with
\(c_1=a_1+b_1,\ c_2=a_2+\tfrac23a_1b_1+b_2,\ c_3=a_3+\tfrac13a_2b_1+\tfrac13a_1b_2+b_3\),
after shifting \(p(x+\alpha),q(x+\beta)\), expanded coefficients satisfy exactly
\(c_1'=c_1+3(\alpha+\beta)\),
\(c_2'=c_2+2c_1(\alpha+\beta)+3(\alpha+\beta)^2\),
\(c_3'=c_3+c_2(\alpha+\beta)+c_1(\alpha+\beta)^2+(\alpha+\beta)^3\),
which is precisely \((p\boxplus_3 q)(x+\alpha+\beta)\).

Hence WLOG centering is valid: choose shifts making new \(a_1=b_1=0\) (e.g. for \(p(x+\alpha)\), take \(\alpha=-a_1/n\)).

For p(x)=x^3+a_2x+a_3 with roots l_1,l_2,l_3 and l_1+l_2+l_3=0: f_i=\sum_{j\ne i}1/(l_i-l_j)=p''(l_i)/(2p'(l_i))=3l_i/p'(l_i), so \Phi_3=9\sum_i l_i^2/p'(l_i)^2. With \Delta=\prod_{i<j}(l_i-l_j)^2 and p'(l_i)=\prod_{j\ne i}(l_i-l_j), we get \Delta/p'(l_1)^2=(l_2-l_3)^2 etc., hence \Phi_3\Delta=9\,S where S=\sum_{cyc} l_1^2(l_2-l_3)^2. Expanding: S=2l_1^2l_2^2-2l_1^2l_2l_3+2l_1^2l_3^2-2l_1l_2^2l_3-2l_1l_2l_3^2+2l_2^2l_3^2. Substituting l_3=-l_1-l_2 gives S=2(l_1^2+l_1l_2+l_2^2)^2. Since e_2=l_1l_2+l_1l_3+l_2l_3=-(l_1^2+l_1l_2+l_2^2)=a_2, we obtain \Phi_3\Delta=18e_2^2=18a_2^2. Therefore 1/\Phi_3=\Delta/(18a_2^2)=(-4a_2^3-27a_3^2)/(18a_2^2)=-2a_2/9-3a_3^2/(2a_2^2). 1/Phi(p)=2s/9-3u^2/(2s^2), 1/Phi(q)=2t/9-3v^2/(2t^2), 1/Phi(conv)=2(s+t)/9-3(u+v)^2/(2(s+t)^2)
